entry.title: Coronavirus and the economy: Can the world cope with more debt? | Counting the Cost

media:group.media:title: Coronavirus and the economy: Can the world cope with more debt? | Counting the Cost
media:group.media:description:
With more than 22 million coronavirus cases and almost 800,000 deaths worldwide, the health crisis is far from over, as countries face second waves of coronavirus cases.
We may have seen some of the worst economic costs, but more pain could be lurking in the months ahead.
Against this backdrop, the United States and China have potentially also inched closer to a new Cold War.
Bilal Hafeez, CEO of Macro Hive; Rajiv Biswas, Asia-Pacific chief economist at IHS Markit; and Robert Quartly-Janeiro from the London School of Economics discuss the most pressing economic and geopolitical questions on post-pandemic recovery.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Qatar: Nature and development at a crossroads | Talk to Al Jazeera

media:group.media:title: Qatar: Nature and development at a crossroads | Talk to Al Jazeera
media:group.media:description:
Qatar is one of the richest nations per capita in the world.
It has experienced rapid development since oil and natural gas were discovered in the Gulf nation in the early 1900s. But the Qatari coastline and its desert are also the sources of a different kind of natural wealth.
If unprotected, Qatar's nature could be endangered as a result of a loss of habitat.
On this edition of Talk to Al Jazeera, we take you on a journey into Qatar's unexplored wildlife and we discuss the effect uncontrolled development could have the environment.

entry.title: Thai student protests: Minister meets organisers

media:group.media:title: Thai student protests: Minister meets organisers
media:group.media:description:
The Thai police have begun arresting student anti-government protest organisers to prevent what officials fear was an escalation. But for the first time, a minister sat down with some of the students. Al Jazeera's Scott Heidler, in Bangkok, asked him how it went.

entry.title: US outbreak: Border towns with poverty suffering the most

media:group.media:title: US outbreak: Border towns with poverty suffering the most
media:group.media:description:
COVID-19 rates are soaring along the United States border with Mexico. A combination of poverty and poor public health infrastructure are putting communities at higher risk than in other areas of the US. Al Jazeera's Rob Reynolds reports.

entry.title: US elections: Biden promises to reverse many of Trump's changes

media:group.media:title: US elections: Biden promises to reverse many of Trump's changes
media:group.media:description:
The United States stance on Iran is one of many major foreign policy areas upended by President Donald Trump. Presidential nominee Joe Biden says he would take a very different approach if he wins in November. Al Jazeera's Mike Hanna reports on how that might look.

entry.title: What happened to Alexei Navalny? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: What happened to Alexei Navalny? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
The leading Russian opposition politician Alexei Navalny is fighting for his life . His family and supporters say he was poisoned. Navalny fell ill during a flight to Moscow. His staff suspect poison was put in his tea at an airport cafe. But doctors have told his wife his condition is 'unstable' and he's 'too ill' to be transferred. Navalny's team says the hospital is blocking his move under pressure from the Kremlin. This is not the first time such an attack has occured. So, are Russian critcs now at risk more than ever?
Presenter: Hashem Ahelbarra
Guests:
Anna Matveeva - Visiting Senior Research Fellow at King's College London.
Daragh McDowell - Principal Russia Analyst at the risk consultancy Verisk Maplecroft.
Ilya Ponomarev - Exiled Russian Politician and a former Member of the State Duma.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #Russia #Poisoning

entry.title: Russia Navalny 'poisoning': German doctors allowed access to the politician

media:group.media:title: Russia Navalny 'poisoning': German doctors allowed access to the politician
media:group.media:description:
The wife of Russian opposition politician Alexei Navalny has appealed to President Vladimir Putin, to allow him to be taken to Germany for treatment. He went into a coma on Thursday with suspected poisoning. A police laboratory says it found traces of an industrial chemical on his body, but Russian doctors say there is no indication he was poisoned. Al Jazeera's Rory Challands reports.

entry.title: Myanmar peace talks: Growing frustration over lack of progress

media:group.media:title: Myanmar peace talks: Growing frustration over lack of progress
media:group.media:description:
Rebel army leaders in Myanmar say they are frustrated by a lack of progress in peace talks with the government. After a delay of more than two years, the fourth round of negotiations with 10 armed groups has concluded in the capital, Naypyidaw. Al Jazeera's Wayne Hay reports from Chiang Mai, in neighbouring Thailand.

entry.title: Joe Biden presents US election as a fight for the nation's soul

media:group.media:title: Joe Biden presents US election as a fight for the nation's soul
media:group.media:description:
US Democrat presidential candidate Joe Biden has formally accepted his party's nomination promising to overcome what he called a "season of darkness". Biden accused President Donald Trump of failing to lead and failing to protect. Al Jazeera's Alan Fisher reports from Wilmington, in Biden's home state of Delaware.

entry.title: Beirut blast aftermath: Search for the missing continues 2 weeks on

media:group.media:title: Beirut blast aftermath: Search for the missing continues 2 weeks on
media:group.media:description:
It has been more than two weeks since one of the largest non-nuclear explosions in history devastated Beirut - and more than 20 people remain missing. Families are desperate for answers, with many calling for an independent investigation. Al Jazeera’s Stefanie Dekker reports.

entry.title: California wildfires: Two dead as fires engulf north of US state

media:group.media:title: California wildfires: Two dead as fires engulf north of US state
media:group.media:description:
A pilot and a man trying to help firefighters have died in wildfires which are engulfing northern California in the United States.
Hundreds of buildings have burned as thousands of people have been forced from their homes near San Francisco. Al Jazeera's Rob Reynolds reports from Los Angeles.

entry.title: Steve Bannon, former Trump adviser, arrested for fraud

media:group.media:title: Steve Bannon, former Trump adviser, arrested for fraud
media:group.media:description:
Former senior White House strategist Steve Bannon has pleaded not guilty to charges of defrauding donors and money laundering. It relates to an online campaign that raised $25m, supposedly to go towards President Donald Trump's US-Mexico border wall. Bannon has been released on bail, set at $5m, but is barred from leaving the country. Al Jazeera's Gabriel Elizondo reports from New York, US.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Trump #Bannon

entry.title: Will Mali's coup leaders hand over power to civilians? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Will Mali's coup leaders hand over power to civilians? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
Mali has seen weeks of anti-government protests and unrest. On Tuesday, its military took charge and forced the resignation of the president. The coup leaders say they want to prevent the nation falling further into chaos. The soldiers have pledged to set up a transitional civilian government and hold elections. The military takeover follows the demand by thousands of Malians for better security, economy and an end to corruption. Former president Ibrahim Boubacar Keita's critics blame him for the country's hardships. So, after weeks of unrest, what's next for this West African nation? And can military takeovers be prevented?
Presenter: Hashem Ahelbarra
Guests
Manu Lekunze - Lecturer at the University of Aberdeen and Author of, 'Inherent and Contemporary Challenges to African Security'.
Susanna Wing - Specialist on West Africa and Associate Professor at Haverford College.
Mohamed Salaha - Journalist and Publisher at LeMaliMag.com, a Malian news website.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: K-pop controversy: Questions over BTS mandatory military service

media:group.media:title: K-pop controversy: Questions over BTS mandatory military service
media:group.media:description:
There is growing controversy surrounding South Korea's most famous boy band. The K-pop stars from BTS are facing questions over when they plan to do military service, as required under the law. Al Jazeera's Rob McBride reports.

entry.title: Venezuela: Opposition leaders promise to boycott elections

media:group.media:title: Venezuela: Opposition leaders promise to boycott elections
media:group.media:description:
In Venezuela, opposition leader Juan Guaido is planning a boycott of the upcoming legislative elections. He is appealing to fractured opposition parties to unite in what has been seen as a last-ditch effort to maintain recognition at home and abroad. Al Jazeera's Lucia Newman reports.
